 They played a sympathetic role - visiting the injured in hospital, expressing their revulsion etc. Personally, although I recognised that the 7/7 bombings were an attack on the nation, I did not associate the event with the fate of the monarchy or expect the Queen to console the national grief.
 
 When disaster strikes, it is the prime minister who addresses the nation. The Queen is not a political figure; her role is symbolic. She speaks to the nation, as a rule, only twice a year. At the opening of parliament she reads the Queen's Speech - a statement of the government's policies which has been written for her by someone in the cabinet. She appears on television to give her "Christmas message"; this is usually a non-political survey of the year that is passing and a reaffirmation of her confidence in the future of Britain etc.
